body:
Updated. Major changes are:
1. The way cancellation is handled. AbstractJobLauncher now has a default implementation of cancelJob that simply sets the flag cancellationRequested (which is volatile boolean), which indicates that cancellation is requested. Then the method will wait (with timeout) on a object named cancellationLock on which notify will be called once the cancellation is successfully executed. No explicit synchronization is needed for cancellationRequested since it is volatile boolean. The responsibility of executing the cancellation is done by a single-thread scheduled thread pool executor named `cancellationExecutor`, which periodically checks if the flag `cancellationRequested` is set and calls a method `executeCancellation` to actually execute the cancellation if the flag is set. If the cancellation is successfully executed, another flag `cancellationExecuted` is set so the `cancellationExecutor` will do a noop if the cancellation has already been executed. The execution of cancellation and setting of the `cancellationExecuted` flag, as well as the check of the flag `cancellationExecuted` in the 'JobLauncher' implementations, are synchronized on `cancellationExecutor` (used as a lock).
2. Added a new class JobContext that contains all context information of a job. This simplifies AbstractJobLauncher.
3. Added a new method `shutdownExecutorService` in `ExecutorUtils` and used it in the code base.
LGTM. Although I'm not entirely sure on the design of the `cancel()` method. Perhaps @chavdar can take a look?

Updated based on discussion with Chavdar.

@liyinan926 any more comments?

I understand that streamlining the state transitions will require some work so I agree we should do that later but I think we should decide on the cancelJob() contract and clean up the implementation. I think this is fairly self-contained work.

@chavdar updated. Can you review? The updates are in the last two commits (c6cf621 and 3c9083c). The last one is a merge commit, but it does include some additional changes on `AbstractJobLauncher`, `LocalJobLauncher`, and `MRJobLauncher`.
LGTM other than two minor comments.
Also, there are too many commits in this PR, please merge them.
@zliu41 I've squashed all the commits into one with rebase. Is that okay?

I believe we also discussed replacing `AvroHdfsDataWriter.CodecType` with `CodecFactory.fromString(String s)` since it will provide a safer option for setting the codec. Do you want to do that in this pull request, or a different one?
I was planning to do the refactor as a different pull request.
LGTM other than the three comments above.
Let's chat in person about the writer.file.name change.
LGTM. In the next pull request, can we also add a unit test for AvroHdfsDataWriter to ensure that it is preserving all the properties properly.
This is not completely related but I think the current implementation of the Extractor needs a major overhaul. I've opened a ticket to follow-up ETL-3070 .
Talked with @chavdar, will merge this first and discuss the semantic change later.

sure. I can do that. 
For the current changes though, the test will have to check the results of a bunch of set commands.
@ibuenros seems there's already some comments from @zliu41 and you may need to wait until #135 is merged. So I will look at this pull request after you address all comments from @zliu41.

I haven't looked too deeply into this PR but had a few questions based on the PR summary:

Does this mean there will be one extractor per topic no matter how many partitions there are? Before, I believe there was 1 task per partition per topic, so the job was parallelized based on partitions, i.e. if there are 10 partitions, there could be 10 different threads pulling from Kafka. Is this now a sequential process?

In the old way (where there was one extractor per partition per topic), we basically wrote this module: https://github.com/linkedin/gobblin/blob/c71a32875a97386d0214dbece53559ccdf8cd875/gobblin-core/src/main/java/gobblin/publisher/BatchKafkaData.java
which can get called from the publisher and basically batches together all kafka data for a given topic. This way, the extractors can still run in parallel, but the data gets batched at the publish step.

Is there a reason the design decision was made to sequentially pull all partitions in a topic?

@akshayn1107 Not all partitions of a topic go to the same workunit/extractor, it depends on the number of mappers (`mr.job.max.mappers`). If that number is more than a third of the total number of partitions, then most likely each workunit will still have only one partition.

If the number of mappers is very small compared to the number of partitions (in our use case we use 200 mappers for 5000+ partitions), then we try to assign partitions of the same topic to the same workunit, so that these partitions can share output files. This helps reduce the number of small files generated.

The number of workunits/extractors is no less than 3x number of mappers. We use `workUnitMaxSize = total size of all partitions / num of mappers / 3`
If the total size of all partitions of a topic is smaller than workUnitMaxSize, all of them go to the same workunit. Otherwise, they go to different workunits via bin packing.

Let me know if this works for you.
@zliu41 Thanks for clarifying, that makes sense.

Chavdar: 

I have addressed the comments you gave, please review it.
Thanks
Min
Came across this, thought it was interesting / relevant: http://docs.guava-libraries.googlecode.com/git/javadoc/com/google/common/util/concurrent/RateLimiter.html
@zliu41 I fixed the bugs you brought up in a new PR, and also added a unit test: https://github.com/linkedin/gobblin/pull/141
Yeah, I didn't notice that. It seems more general and handles bursty requests. I changed `RateBasedLimiter` to use that.
Yinan, I've tested and it worked. LGTM.
@chavdar do you want to take a look?
@liyinan926 @zliu41 PR has been updated and merged with the new KafkaExtractor. Can you take a look?
No more comments from me. Once Yinan's comments have been addressed, you can merge.
LGTM. There are too many commits in this PR, please squash some of them before merging.

LGTM.
It seems this is not for fixing finbugs warnings, but style fixes? I submitted PR 147 fixing the warnings as well.
It fixed the two new high priority warnings around use of static non-final variable.
Closing the Timer.Context does nothing but record the time. I think ensuring a close just possibly produces bad metrics without any benefit.
OK, I didn't realize that. I was just thinking based on the name that it returns a `MetricContext`, which should be properly closed.
@liyinan926 @zliu41 @chavdar can two of you review this PR? Thanks!

@liyinan926 , I just have one question. With this fix, if start or end time is not set, then JobExecutionInfo/TaskExecutionInfo basically would still be constructed but not contain the start/end time. Is that right?
We have to add the license header to every new file created. For example, the build.gradle file has the proper license header. Can you copy that header to every other new file.
Can you also add a bit more detail into this Pull Request, about what each interface is responsible for, and how the interfaces are documented. It would be best if this is all documented.

I had a few thoughts about the interface layout. None of this is necessary, they are just some ideas I had:

A `TestHarnessLauncher` interface, it simply has a `launchJob(Properties props)` method, which takes in a Java `Properties` object. The TestHarnessLauncher is responsible for launching all the integration tests. The given `props` object contains global configuration properties. The `props` object also points to a directory containing the individual test files. The `launchJob` method takes all these test files, loads them into memory and creates a `IntegrationTest` for each one. Each `IntegrationTest` can composed of a series of `SetupOperators`, a single `JobLauncher`, and a series of `ValidationOperators`.

1: Is `Validator` still necessary now that `ValidationRule` is present? Same with `Operator` and `SetupOperator`
2: Can we remove the unnecessary dependencies from the `build.gradle`
3: Which interface is the Driver? What class gets invoked first? Is it `ConfigReader`?
